questions.flashCardFront: IARC stands for:
questions.flashCardBack: International Agency for Research on Cancer.

answers.answer: International Agency for Research on Cancer.

questions.flashCardFront: Occupational exposure limits (OEL's) are:
questions.flashCardBack: Academically derived maximum limits with no legal force in Ontario.

answers.answer: The legal maximum exposure limits in Ontario for a typical 40-hour work week, 8 hours a day.
Academically derived maximum limits with no legal force in Ontario.
The minimum level that a worker in Ontario should be exposed to for a 40-hour week with 8 hour days.

questions.flashCardFront: What does WHMIS stand for?

answers.answer: Workers and Hazardous Materials in Science

questions.flashCardFront: Hazards of cryogens include the following:

answers.answer: Frostbite, asphyxiation, eye injury, liquid oxygen concentration.
Frostbite, with cool smoke effects in drinks or pools.

questions.flashCardFront: If a supplier WHMIS label is missing or damaged, it should be promptly replaced with any of the following:
questions.flashCardBack: spare supplier WHMIS label or section 2 of the SDS

answers.answer: spare supplier WHMIS label or section 2 of the SDS

questions.flashCardFront: Eyewashes need to be tested because:
questions.flashCardBack: Water can be turned off accidentally (e.g. during maintenance work) and will not be available in an emergency.

answers.answer: It provides work for lab staff.
It is fun to watch the water flow.
Water can be turned off accidentally (e.g. during maintenance work) and will not be available in an emergency.
It is part of the scientific process

questions.flashCardFront: The is good evidence that nanomaterials produce amplified or more targeted effects versus larger particle size versions of the same material.
Students are not protected by the University Health and Safety Policy because it only covers employees.
TA's are relied upon to provide guidance for activities that undergraduate students may not be able to conduct on their own.
No permit is ever required for use of chemicals.
There are no special requirements around building, renovating or decommissioning a lab.
Eyewashes need to be tested regularly, and that testing needs to be noted on a tag or sheet (documented).
It is OK to go to the lunch room in your lab coat and gloves.
There is no need to use nanomaterials in a fume hood or biosafety cabinet.
The labels on purchased lasers are always correct.
A TWA is the legally acceptable average airborne concentration for a 40-hour work week.
Accidentally mixing organic solvents with acid waste can lead to an explosion.
You need radiation safety training to use an open source above the exemption limit.
Safety glasses are part of basic lab PPE.
Not purging oxygen from a sealed tube before inserting it in liquid nitrogen can result in an explosion.
